title-group.article-title: A Controversy over Rhyme and Authorship in Pericles

body.p: MACDONALD JACKSON attempts in his book-length study of the authorship of Pericles1 to demonstrate the ‘dual authorship’ of the play, and then to identify the authors as George Wilkins and William Shakespeare. Jackson believes that a study of rhyme can help to establish these conclusions, and this conviction has led to a disagreement between us that has emerged in articles in Notes and Queries on the subject of ‘rhyme and authorship’.2 In responding to my essay, Jackson acknowledges that he has mistakenly claimed ‘uniqueness or near uniqueness’ of some rhyme-links between Pericles, I–II and Wilkins’ Miseries of Enforced Marriage; and his own research has led him to withdraw the claim that the ‘high-rhyming, assonant, rifted, rafted style’ found in the first two Acts of Pericles is the ‘trademark’ of Wilkins (‘Rhymes and Authors’, 264–5). For the most part, however, Jackson defends the arguments and conclusions of his book; and his defence requires serious examination.

I contend that rhyme of itself is not a sign that different authors composed the two ‘parts’ of the play as it has come to be divided. When one calculates the ratio of all rhymed to verse lines in Pericles, the results are similar: 31 per cent for Acts I–II (281/903), 25 per cent for Acts III–V (260/1032).3 But Jackson finds reason to exclude evidence. Not all rhymes should be counted, he argues, only those that appear in verse-dialogue. After this exclusion, the figures (based on the numbers of E. K. Chambers, who considerably undercounted the extra-choral rhymes in III–IV) are much different: 25 per cent for I–II, vs. 3 per cent for III–V.4 Do these radically disparate percentages by themselves demonstrate dual authorship? They do not. There is no reason to privilege percentages based on truncation over those that are not. The scaled-back numbers eliminate from consideration 85 per cent of the rhymed lines in Acts III–V (222 out of 260)—all of them lines spoken by Gower, not ‘external’ verses (as Chambers called them) but lines essential to the play’s story. The speeches containing them were probably written by the author responsible for the rest of the verse in the final three Acts. In studying the rhymes-to-verses ratio in Hamlet, should one eliminate the ‘external’ verses of the Player’s speech and of the ‘Mousetrap’? In considering the rhyme patterns of Romeo and Juliet, should one ignore the ‘external’ sonnet-prologues of Acts I and II while taking into account the ‘internal’ sonnet-rhymes in I.v? (It should be noted that Chambers made the distinction primarily to highlight differences in meter, not in rhyme.5) Jackson claims that adding Gower’s rhymes to those in the dialogue ‘simply blurs a crucial stylistic distinction between two ‘halves’ of the play’ (‘Rhymes and Authors’, 262). I would say that in each ‘half’ of the play the stylistic relationship of the choral lines to the dialogue-verses is essentially the same, and that Gower’s share of the verse in the second half is much greater (225 lines in III–V vs. 82 in I–II) because in the latter part, by the very nature of his tale, greater resort to narration is needed. Mere numbers in this case cannot reliably distinguish between different authors.

Bringing Shakespeare into the picture does not change matters. Jackson assumes that the verse-dialogue rhyming rate of ‘3 per cent’ (5 per cent, in fact) associates Pericles, III–V with Shakespeare’s practice in the later tragedies and the other romances, written at the same stage of his career.6 Only one other play in the canon, however, Henry V, features a Chorus whose rhymes constitute, as they do in III–V, as much as 85 per cent of the total. In this respect, the writing in these Acts is not really comparable with that of the late Shakespeare.7 On the other hand, Jackson claims that ‘there is no play by Shakespeare alone in which two consecutive Acts have as many as 25 per cent of verse-dialogue lines rhymed while remaining Acts have as few as 3 per cent’. Yet, as already suggested, there are different ways of approaching the problem of percentages. Much of the discrepancy disappears when all rhymes are considered: the ‘amounts of rhyme’ are no longer, as Jackson asserts, ‘wildly different’ (‘Rhymes and Authors’, 261). But even if one were to take into account only verse-dialogue, at least two plays ‘by Shakespeare alone’ show a significant divergence in rhyming between two consecutive Acts and the other three: The Merchant of Venice and King Lear (1608 Quarto text).8 This variance shows itself first in the absolute number of rhymed lines in the dialogue: 132 in Merchant, I–III, and 18 in IV–V; 139 in Lear, I–III, and 22 in IV–V; compare 199 in Pericles, I–II, and 38 in III–V. In each of these plays, there is more than an 80 per cent difference in rhyming lines between three contiguous Acts and the other two Acts. Since, however, Acts may vary considerably in size, it is necessary to secure the bases of comparison by considering the ratios of rhymed lines in the dialogue of each part in relation to the total number of verse lines in that dialogue. The results are as follows:
Per, I–II: 24 per cent; Per, III–V: 5 per cent (or, 199/821; 38/807)
MV, I–III: 10 per cent; MV, IV–V: 2 per cent (or, 132/1273; 18/756)
Lr, I–III: 10 per cent, Lr; IV–V: 2 per cent (or, 139/1345; 22/1010)
Thus the ‘discrepancy’ in rhyming practices between the divided parts of the three plays, two of which are, no one would doubt, entirely by Shakespeare, is virtually the same: in each work, the percentage of rhymed lines per verses is approximately five times greater in one part than in the other. The comparison shows that a large disparity in the number of lines rhymed in two parts of a play need not be a sign of dual authorship, and need not exclude the possibility of authorship by Shakespeare.

Analysing the numerical distinctions above with the chi-square test, a form of statistical analysis that Jackson often employs, one would conclude that the two parts of Merchant and Lear, as well as of Pericles, belong to different ‘populations’ (by different authors?)—as is evidently not the case.9 The test fails in this situation, as it would in others, because it is applied to rhymes, which are not demonstrably (as is assumed with chi-square tests) random variables with approximately normal probability distributions.10 Each rhyme is the product of conscious choice; the frequency and placement of rhymes are also at some level consciously chosen. It is clear that Shakespeare decided at times to distribute his rhymes with great unevenness in some of his plays, in a way that would not disqualify him from the authorship of both parts of Pericles.

Jackson is concerned not only with rhyming in general, but with a specific rhyming vocabulary shared by Wilkins in his ‘sole unaided play’, The Miseries of Enforced Marriage, with the author(s) of Pericles. Finding in Pericles, I–II 21 different rhymes (‘types’) that appear in Miseries, and only six such rhymes in Pericles, III–V (by Shakespeare), Jackson believes that ‘this very large discrepancy’ strengthens the case that he has made on other grounds ‘against Shakespeare’s authorship of Pericles, I–II’ (‘Rhymes and Authors’, 262). The first part of Pericles shares 15.7 per cent of its types (21 rhymes out of a total of 134) with Miseries; the second part, only 4.5 per cent (6 out of a total of 133).11 By this reasoning, however, Romeo and Juliet would also seem to be co-authored, showing a similar discrepancy: Acts I–II of Romeo share twenty-two rhymes (types) with Miseries, and Acts III–V share four, a difference between 13.8 per cent (22/160) and 4.8 per cent (4/84):

sec.title: Rhymes shared by Romeo and Juliet with The Miseries of Enforced Marriage
Romeo and Miseries:
sec.p: Taking into account rhymed ‘tokens’ (i.e. all instances of the different rhymes, including repetitions), one could come to the same conclusion about Romeo and Juliet’s co-authorship. Romeo, I–II shares 28 of its 174 tokens (22 rhymes + 6 repeats) with Miseries, and Romeo, III–V shares 5 of its 88 (4 rhymes + 1 repeat), a discrepancy between 16.1 per cent and 5.7 percent—comparable to Pericles, I–II, which shares 26 of 146 tokens (21 rhymes + 5 repeats) with Miseries, and Pericles, III–V, which shares 6 of 135 (6 rhymes and no repeats), a difference between 17.8 per cent and 4.4 per cent.

The repetitions of which I speak here are those which occur in Romeo and Juliet and in Pericles, and they show that the rhyming lexicon of Miseries is used in each of those two plays in a similar pattern. If repetition suggests a writer’s predilection for a rhyme, how are Wilkins’ predilections, as shown in the repeated rhymes of Miseries, to be compared with those of the author(s) of Romeo and Pericles? Jackson does not in Defining Shakespeare make a direct comparison. He creates what he terms ‘links’ between the rhymes in Miseries and those of the other plays by multiplying the number of instances of each shared rhyme (2 occurrences of life/wife in Pericles, I–II × 6 in Miseries = 12 links), adding up the number of links between Miseries and each of the other plays or parts of plays, dividing each sum by the number of rhymes in each play or part, and comparing the quotients (see Defining Shakespeare, 103). I have questioned this procedure, suggesting that the numbers so generated offer no definite insight into the rhyming practices of different authors (‘Rhyme and Authorship’, 396–97), and Jackson has given only a brief reply to my objection, saying that his method is consistently applied and that it recognizes the necessity of considering tokens as well as types (‘Rhyme and Authorship’, 263). One can apply my argument to the case of Romeo and Juliet. In his book, Jackson reports fifty-eight multiplied rhyming links between Miseries and Pericles, I–II, at a ratio to all rhyme-tokens in I–II of 40.0 per cent; and fifty-five such links (59, by my count) between Miseries and Romeo, at a ratio of 21.7 per cent (Defining Shakespeare, 103). This discrepancy is indeed large, but its meaning is indeterminate. Kiss/this contributes two rhymes to the total shared by Miseries and Romeo, I–II, four to the total shared by Miseries and Pericles, I–II, and the totals may be meaningfully compared. The product ‘eight’, the number of links, is a single quantity that applies to nothing in either play and elides the differences that make for a proper comparison, as may be shown.

There is a great disparity in the outcomes produced by the two schemes of computation. In Method A, when sums of rhyme-tokens in Romeo and Pericles are compared, the ratios of rhymes shared with Miseries to all rhymes in the two ‘parts’ of the target plays are, as noted above, negligibly different: Romeo, I–II, 16.1 per cent; Pericles, I–II, 17.8 per cent; Romeo, III–V, 5.7 per cent; Pericles, III–V, 4.4 per cent. In Method B, the multiplication of token numbers across the plays produces a markedly dissimilar result, with the ratios of links per rhyme-tokens being: Romeo, I–II, 27.6 per cent (48/174); Pericles, I–II, 39.7 per cent (58/146); Romeo, III–V, 12.5 per cent (11/88); Pericles, III–V, 9.6 per cent (13/135). The reasons for the differences are not difficult to perceive. The numerators, in determining the percentages, change from sums to the sums of products, and the denominators do not.

But what is the effect of the changes, and which method offers a truer picture of rhyming practices? Both procedures make use of links (differently calculated); both take into account repetitions. But Method B, employed by Jackson, does not in fact indicate the authors’ relative rhyming preferences, as we can see from the following illustration. The rhyme ill/will occurs on a percentage basis three times more often in Miseries than in Romeo, I–II (6 instances out of 296 rhymes = 2.0 per cent; 1/174 = 0.6 per cent). Method A proceeds in a way that takes the difference into account. Method B disguises the difference by conflating the numbers that reveal it. A single instance of ill/will in Romeo, I–II now contributes to 6 links that the text is said to have with Miseries, the numerators becoming the same in the ratio of links (not rhymes) to rhyme-tokens (6/174 = 3.4 per cent; 6/296 = 2.0 per cent). With a much smaller relative frequency of occurrence in Romeo, I–II than in Miseries (as indicated in Method A), ill/will shows a larger percentage of links (as defined in Method B) between the two works. Whatever ‘links’ may mean in this case, they reveal nothing about comparative rhyming preference. Similarly, comparing appearances of ill/will in Miseries and in Pericles, I–II shows that it appears with the same frequency in both texts (6/296 = 2.0 per cent; 3/146 = 2.1 per cent); but the sameness becomes a distinct difference in the ratio of links (6 × 3) to rhyme-tokens (18/296 = 6.1 per cent; 18/146 = 12.3 per cent).

In Method B, ill/will, one rhyme-type out of twenty-one shared is made to account for 31 per cent (18/58) of all the links between Miseries and Pericles, I–II. Two rhyme-types, ill/will and life/wife, account for over 50 per cent (30/58).

According to this method, if a text X and a text Y both contain 400 rhymes, but X has two instances of hay/day and Y has twenty, each would contain the same ratio of links to rhymes, 40/400, though in one text hay/day appeared ten times more frequently than in the other.12 Is this better than Method A as a means to represent and compare authorial practice in the use of rhyme?

Method A also has its limitations. If a play, The Agony, with 200 rhyme-tokens has ten rhyme-types in common with Miseries, each type occurring four times in The Agony, it exhibits the same percentage of shared to all rhyme-tokens, 40/200 or 20 per cent, as does another play, The Ecstasy, also with 200 rhyme tokens, which had forty rhyme-types shared with Miseries, but none repeated. Thus it is interesting that Jackson, in ‘Rhymes and Authors’ (264), takes up the matter of rhyming preferences in a different way. Confining his attention first to specific rhymes that occur more than twice in Miseries, he finds that there are six instances of such favored rhymes in Pericles, I–II (based on ill/will, kiss/this, life/wife) and four instances in all of Romeo (based on ill/will, kiss/this), revealing a discrepancy in the rate of occurrence. According to his counts, the difference is between a rate of 4.1 per cent (6/145) for Pericles, I–II and 1.6 per cent (4/254) for all of Romeo.13 Wilkins’ favourites, then, are more favoured in the first two Acts of Pericles than in Romeo. But not quite in the way and to the extent that Jackson suggests. There is always a statistical hazard in making use of such small numbers. Nevertheless, comparing Pericles, I–II with Romeo, I–II instead of with the entire play, and considering the rhymes individually, one can see that ill/will is more favoured in the first part of Pericles (3/146 = 2.1 per cent; 1/174 = 0.6 per cent, but that kiss/this is preferred in the first part of Romeo (2/174 = 1.1 per cent; 1/146 = 0.7 per cent). Life/wife breaks the ‘draw’, appearing twice in Pericles, I–II and not at all in Romeo. This is hardly a decisive victory. The two occurrences of this rhyme in Pericles, I–II show it to be less favoured here than in Miseries, with its six instances (2/146 = 1.4 per cent; 6/296 = 2.0 per cent). Life/wife appears also, once, in the Shakespearian Pericles, III–V; and on occasion elsewhere Shakespeare can show a stronger predilection for it than is evinced in Pericles, I–II, using it twice in a single scene of Comedy of Errors (III.ii), and twice in a single stanza of Lucrece (1800–1806). Jackson does not compare the rates of occurrence in the first parts of Pericles and Romeo of rhymes that appear at least twice in Miseries. This larger number of Wilkins’ favourites is in fact used with equal frequency in both of the other texts: 12 times in the 174 rhymes in Romeo, I–II (6.9 per cent); 10 times in the 146 rhymes in Pericles, I–II (6.8 per cent), with similar distribution of single appearances and repeats: in the first part of Romeo, 5 one-rhyme, 2 two-rhyme, and 1 three-rhyme instances; in the first part of Pericles, 3 one-rhyme, 2 two-rhyme, and 1 three-rhyme instances.14

The conclusion of this analysis must be, of course, not that both Romeo and Juliet and Pericles were written by two authors, one of whom may have been in each case George Wilkins, but that rhyming patterns are untrustworthy markers of authorship.

Another problem brought into focus by Jackson in his response to my article is the likelihood, or even the inevitability, that readers will disagree on whether certain word-doublets in fact constitute rhymes. Jackson and I are at odds, for example, over some assonantal rhymes that may or may not interrupt or be interrupted by blank verse (‘rafts’ or ‘rifts’).15 Jackson is also certain that him rhymes with sin in Pericles, but not, as I claim, in Measure for Measure. The passage in dispute appears at the end of Measure, IV.i:
To bring you thus together ‘tis no sin,
Sith that the justice of your title to him
Doth flourish the deceit. Come, let us go,
Our corn’s to reap, for yet our tithe’s to sow. (72–75) Jackson’s criteria for a rhyme include a stress on the words in question (‘Rhymes and Authors’, 263) and placement ‘at a position in a speech or scene in which rhyme is often used’ (‘Rhymes and Authors’, 266). I believe that both requirements are satisfied in this case. Him is, like sin, indeed stressed, after an unmarked elision (‘t’ him’); otherwise, the accent would fall awkwardly on the preposition, and the line would contain an unnecessary syllable. Furthermore, the rhyming pattern evident here appears elsewhere in the play at the end of scenes (cf. die/chastity/request/rest [II.iv]; incline/mine/show/know [V.i]); and the end of a scene is in general ‘a position … in which rhyme is often used’. It might also be noted that Shakespeare rhymes win with him assonantally in lines of a song at a scene’s end (win/him/speak/break) (Troilus, III.iii.212–13). Of the twelve assonantal rhymes in Shakespeare’s plays that I add to the list of D. J. Lake (‘Rhyme and Authorship’, 399–400), Jackson, as is his right, doubts all but one of them. But of the eleven questioned, Helge Kökeritz, in Shakespeare’s Pronunciation,16 records eight; a ninth is him/sin, for which I’ve argued; and a tenth, doom/gone is conceded by Jackson to be ‘possible’ (‘Rhymes and Authors’, 265–6). Since Kökeritz’s inventory is the basis for all of the figures about rhymes given in Jackson’s study (Defining Shakespeare, 99; ‘Rhymes and Authors’, 263), it is surprising to see in this case such widespread disagreement with an essential source, whose judgements Jackson nowhere else disputes on such a scale.

That some rhymes (though certainly not most) are so difficult to agree upon compromises their effectiveness in the investigation of authorship, adding to doubts already raised that rhyming practice by itself can distinguish and identify authors in Pericles. MacDonald Jackson’s studies have taken many paths in his attempt to show that the hand of George Wilkins may be seen in this play; but his analysis of rhymes has contributed much less to the process of proof than he has proposed.

Blakemore Evans, et al., 2nd edn (Boston, 1997). Except where noted otherwise, all citations from Shakespeare’s works are from this edition. In this essay, I use my own figures, except when specifically referring to numbers in Jackson’s own calculations.

4 See Jackson, ‘Rhymes and Authors’, 261. By my reckoning, the numbers should be 24 per cent (199/821) vs. 5 per cent (38/807). Chambers reported 22 instead of 38 rhymed lines in the verse outside of the Gower Choruses and the Epilogue of Pericles, III–V. He also, unlike contemporary editors, assigned all of the choral lines in the play and the Epilogue to ‘Non-Shakespeare’. See William Shakespeare: A Study of Facts and Problems (Oxford, 1930), II, 403.

5 Facts and Problems, II, 406: ‘I have placed in the column headed ‘External’ all prologues, epilogues, and choruses, the interludes and masks in M.N.D., A.Y.L., Ham., M.W., Mac., Cy., and Tp., the player’s speech in Ham., and the bombastic lines of Pistol in 2 Hen. IV, Hen. V, and M.W. The metrical quality of these is naturally distinct from that of the plays in which they are related’. The rationale for Chambers’ division is not entirely clear. Equally ‘distinct’ from their contexts are, for example, the ‘metrical qualities’ of ‘internal’ passages of verse from the casket scenes in MV, the tetrameter verse in MM, the Fool’s and the disguised Edgar’s verse in Lr, and the songs in various plays.

6 The 5 per cent figure places Pericles, III–V rather with plays ranging chronologically from King John to Measure for Measure. See Stanley Wells, Gary Taylor, et al., William Shakespeare: A Textual Companion (Oxford, 1987), 96.

7 It is of course possible that the whole play might be structurally in some respects entirely sui generis for Shakespeare, so that the great number of ‘speech-pause rhymes’ in Pericles, I–II and their (arguable) absence in III–V need not require the hypothesis of dual authorship. See Jackson, ‘Rhymes and Authors’, 261; Klause, ‘Rhyme and Authorship’, 399.
8 Analysis of the Lear Quarto is here based on the Oxford edition of the text, as printed in The Norton Shakespeare, ed. Stephen Greenblatt, et al. (New York, 1997).

9 The chi-square values (adjusted with the Yates correction) for Pericles, Merchant, and Lear are, respectively, 123.2, 43.1, and 59.0—all indicating a probability of less than 1 in 10,000 that the large deviations between the rhyme-to-verse ratios in the dialogue of the different ‘parts’ of the plays are due to chance.
10 The importance of this consideration has been suggested to me by Thomas Merriam in personal correspondence.
11 See Defining Shakespeare, 98–103, Tables 12–13. My count of the total number of rhyme-types and tokens is often slightly, not significantly different from Jackson’s.

12 Jackson asserts that such an ‘extreme result’ would never occur with ‘any Shakespeare play’ (‘Rhymes and Authors’, 263), because none has so many repeated rhymes. But with multiplied links, the extremity can come entirely or mostly from the ‘other’ compared play—as it does in the case of Miseries, with its multipliers of 6, 6, and 4, which are larger than any furnished by Romeo or Pericles. Besides, with multiplied links, as has been shown, even less ‘extreme results’ can produce distortions.

14 Jackson also compares the rate of repetition of rhyme-types appearing at least twice in Miseries (8.5 per cent) with the rate in Pericles, I–II (8.6 per cent), and distinguishes these similar percentages sharply from that for Pericles, III–V (1.6 per cent), closely associating Miseries with the first part of Pericles, and dissociating it from the second part (‘Rhymes and Authors’, 265). He does not note, however, that in Romeo, I–II, repeated rhyme-types constitute 8.1 per cent of the total (13/160), and in Romeo, III–V, 4.8 per cent(4/84). The difference in percentages between Pericles, III–V and Romeo, III–V is due to a difference of less than 3 repeated rhymes.
15 Cf. ‘Rhyme and Authorship’, 397–400, and ‘Rhymes and Authors’, 261, 265–6.
